metadata.title: Arthritis, Juvenile Idiopathic  Occupational Therapy
synonyms: still's disease, juvenile onset: occupational therapy
description: Juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA) is the most common chronic rheumatic illness in children and causes significant disability(1,2)
JIA is recognized as a heterogeneous group of diseases with the common factor being onset of arthritis beginning before 16 years of age(2,27)
Signs of JIA: Joint swelling, limited ROM, pain or tenderness, warmth, redness(1,2) –Diagnosis is made after symptoms are present for ≥6 weeks(1)

According to the International League of Associations for Rheumatology, there are 7 subtypes of JIA:(1) –Systemic (Still disease):Ten percent of JIA cases,(1) ≥ 1 joint involvement, onset is typically with or preceded by fever lasting at least 2 weeks that is documented to be daily for at least 3 days and accompanied by 1 or more of the following: evanescent erythematous rash, generalized lymphadenopathy, hepatomegaly or splenomegaly, serositis;(1,2,29) often affects knees, wrists, and ankles and also affects fingers, neck, and hips;(2) the majority of patients test negative for rheumatoid factor (RF) and antinuclear antibodies (ANAs)(29) –Polyarticular RF Positive: Five to 10% of cases,(1) large and small joint involvement (≥ 5 joints),often symmetrical joint involvement, RF+ on at least 2 tests at least 3 months apart(1,2) –Polyarticular RF Negative:Ten to 30% of cases,(1) large and small joint involvement (≥ 5 joints), also affects cervical spine and temporomandibular joint (TMJ), symmetric or asymmetric involvement, RF test negative(2) –Oligoarticular: Thirty to 60% of cases, the most common form of JIA,(1) involvement of 1–4 joints, usually affects large joints of the lower extremities (knees, ankles) with upper extremity involvement less common;(2) increased risk of chronic uveitis in young girls and axial skeletal involvement in older boys,(1) two subcategories:  -Persistent oligoarthritis: ≤ 4 joints affected throughout the disease course(2) -Extended oligoarthritis: > 4 joints affected after first 6 months of disease onset(2) –Psoriatic arthritis: Five percent of cases, arthritis with psoriasis or with at least 2 of the following: dactylitis, nail changes, first-degree  relative with psoriasis,(1) affects small and medium-sized joints, asymmetric joint involvement(2) –Enthesitis-related  arthritis: One to 7% of cases, oligo-polyarthritis  in large or small joints and enthesitis plus any 2 of the following: sacroiliac or lumbosacral pain, acute anterior uveitis, HLA-B27  (+) antigen, ankylosing spondylitis, inflammatory bowel disease, or family history of Reiter syndrome;(1) predominantly affects the lower limbs, with possible axial skeleton involvement(2) –Undifferentiated arthritis: arthritis that does not fit in above categories or fits ≥ 2 categories(1,2)

Incidence and prevalence vary among ethnic and geographic populations(25) –Annual incidence in developed nations: 2 to 20 per 100,000 children < 16 years of age(1) –Global annual incidence of 0.008 to 0.226 per 1,000 children(25) –Prevalence in developed nations: 16 to 150 per 100,000 children < 16 years of age(1) –Global prevalence is estimated to be 0.07 to 4.1 per 1,000 children(25)
For more information on idiopathic juvenile arthritis, see Clinical Review…Juvenile Idiopathic Arthritis ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T708443

M08.M08.2: juvenile rheumatoid arthritis with systemic onset

reimbursement: No specific issues or information regarding reimbursement has been identified. In the United States, financial resources and services may be available through state-funded  programs and through the child’s school district if the child qualifies for services through the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act (IDEA)

Presentation/signs and symptoms –Intraarticular joint swelling(2) –Limited ROM and joint hypomobility(2) -TMJ arthritis occurs in up to 80% of children with JIA and in all subtypes(28) –Tenderness or pain with joint mobility(2) –Increased heat or erythema upon palpation of affected joints(2) –Initial symptoms may include morning stiffness, limping after inactivity(2) –Easy fatigability(2) –Poor sleep quality(2) –Leg-length  discrepancy due to arthritis in large lower extremity joints that affects linear growth(2) -Hip joint is affected in one third of children, with progressive joint destruction, pain, and deformity(27) -Chronic inflammation causes premature closure of the growth plate, causing shortened bones(2) -Children are often of small stature and lower weight(18) –Systemic JIA(2) -Fever, daily for at least 2 weeks (often present in the evening) -Fever present with rash – salmon-colored  lesions, linear or circular, commonly over the trunk and proximal extremities -Hepatosplenomegaly -Lymphadenopathy  -Serositis (pericarditis) -Joint pain and swelling(25) –Polyarticular arthritis(2) -Rheumatoid nodules on elbows, spine, and over the Achilles tendon; unusual, but indicate more severe disease course; almost exclusively occur in RF+ type -Micrognathia with chronic TMJ involvement -Eye conditions -Uveitis(1,2) -2.9% overall incidence of new cases based on a cohort of 1,104 Canadian children(19) -Reported in 10–20%  of patients with JIA(24) -Can lead to significant ocular damage and blindness(24) -Cataracts(24) -Related to the duration of uveitis, degree of inflammation control, and use of topical corticosteroids(24) Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors

contraindications precautions to test: Caution should be exercised regarding the amount of resistance used for exercise programs, as excessive resistive exercises can cause increased inflammation of the joints
Pain should be respected; pain management is an important factor in patient compliance with therapy programs

Patients prescribed NSAIDs are at risk for renal disease, peptic ulcers, GI hemorrhage, leukopenia, and CNS reactions. NSAIDs may also interact with other prescription medications (e.g., diuretics and anticonvulsants). NSAIDs may increase serum levels of methotrexate(1)
Patients prescribed disease-modifying  antirheumatic drugs (DMARDs) are at risk for bone marrow suppression, hepatitis, renal disease, renal toxicity, dermatitis, and mouth ulcers(1)
Patients prescribed TNF inhibitors (TNFi) are at increased risk for infection(1)
Chronic uveitis is a significant complication of JIA(2,19)
Osteoporosis and avascular necrosis are complications associated with JIA(1)

causes: Etiology of JIA is not completely understood, though it is attributed to multiple factors including:(1,2)–Autoimmune disease with environmental and genetic contributing factors(3)–Immunodysregulation involving T lymphocytes(1,2)–Genetic predisposition;(1) multiple genes may affect susceptibility(2)-Human leukocyte antigen (HLA) class I and II alleles(1)-HLA-A2  associated with early-onset oligoarthritis in girls(1)-HLA-DRB1*11  associated with systemic and oligoarthritis(1)-HLA-B27  associated with enthesitis-related JIA(1)-HLA-DR4  associated with polyarticular RF+(1)-Polymorphisms in genes producing protein tyrosine phosphatase nonreceptor 22 (PTPN22), tumor necrosis factor-alpha(TNF-α),  macrophage inhibitory factor, interleukin (IL)-6,  and IL-1α(2)-IL-1(36)  and IL-6 are associated with systemic JIA(2,29)–Environmental or nongenetic triggers(1,2)-Bacterial and viral infections(2)-Heightened immune responses to heat shock proteins(2)-Rubella or parvovirus B19(1)-Infections in combination with genetic susceptibility(3)-Abnormal reproductive hormone levels(2)-Joint trauma(2)
pathogenesis: Immunologic abnormalities result in inflammatory synovitis(2)

Primary disease feature of JIA is synovial inflammation(36)–Hypertrophy and hyperplasia of synovial tissue with hyperemia and edema(2)–Mononuclear and plasma cells (predominantly T lymphocytes) infiltrate the synovium(2)–Tissue secretes cytokines – inflammatory response(4)–Tissue secretes proteolytic enzymes – injury to joint structures(4)–Pannus formation and progressive erosion of articular cartilage and adjacent bone in advanced and uncontrolled disease(2)

A study that used contrast-enhanced  MRI of the knee to compare children unaffected and affected by JIA indicated thatmild synovial thickening could occur in children unaffected by the disease; however, synovial thickening of infrapatellarand/or cruciate ligaments is characteristic of JIA(36)

The inflammatory process underlying systemic JIA differs from other subtypes, particularly due to its lack of a strongmajor histocompatibility complex (MHC) association, presence of cytokine dysregulation, and various innate immunesystem abnormalities(33)
risk factors: Genetics–Evidence of heritability of JIA; a sibling of a patient with JIA is 15 to 30 times more likely to develop JIA(33)
RF positivity associated with polyarticular arthritis and overall poor prognosis(1)
ANA positivity associated with oligoarticular arthritis and may increase risk of uveitis(1)
Sex–Varies depending on the subtype of JIA; overall, females more likely to be affected than males (ratio of 3:1)(1,4)

Age–Typically, onset occurs in preschool-aged  children but varies with subtype(4)-Systemic: onset throughout childhood, with peak onset at 1–5 years of age(2)-Polyarticular RF Positive: onset during late childhood or adolescence(1)-Polyarticular RF Negative: early peak onset at 2–4years of age and late peak at 6–12  years of age(1)-Oligoarticular: peak onset at 2–4 years of age(1)-Psoriatic: early peak onset at 2–3 years of age and late peak at 10–12  years of age(1)-Enthesitis-related:  early peak onset at 2–4 years of age and late peak at 6–12  years of age(1)
Race–Forty percent of children in whom oligoarticular JIA is newly diagnosed are White(25)–Children of African, East Indian, or Native American descent are more likely to have polyarticular JIA(4)

overall contraindications precautions: Only those contraindications/precautions applicable to this diagnosis are mentioned below, including with regard to modalities. Rehabilitation professionals should always use their professional judgment

Patients with this diagnosis are at risk for falls; follow facility protocols for fall prevention and post fall-prevention instructions at bedside, if inpatient. Ensure that patient and family/caregivers are aware of the potential for falls and educated about fall-prevention strategies. Discharge criteria should include independence with fall-prevention strategies
See specific  Contraindications/precautions to examination   and  Contraindications/precautions   under Assessment/

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: Document when symptoms started and how symptoms have progressed since onset. Document what joints are involved

course of treatment.medical management: Medical management Medical management and treatment regimens vary according to the subtype of JIA(25) Treatment goals include disease remission, preventing or stopping progression of joint damage, and promoting normal development(2) Most common surgical interventions Total hip or knee replacement due to severe joint disease.(1) The longevity of a total hip arthroplasty (THA) is reduced in children with JIA, and revision surgeries are quite challenging due to patients’ small proportions and compromised bone density. Intraoperative and early complication rates are relatively high(27) Soft tissue release(1) Limb length/angular deformity corrections(1) Epiphysiodesis (growth plate fusion)(5) Arthrodesis (joint fusion)(5) Synovectomy (rare)(1) Autologous stem cell transplantation(6)  for children with severe resistant JIA; however, risk of treatment-related morbidity and mortality is very high Surgical removal of cataracts with intraocular lens implantation (simultaneously with cataract removal or postponed implantation)(24) Italian researchers reported significantly lower incidence of secondary glaucoma in children who received intraocular transplantation 1116 months following cataract removal compared to those children who received transplantation immediately(24)
course of treatment.medications: Determine what medications clinician has prescribed; are they being taken? Firstline treatment includes NSAIDs and corticosteroids.(1) Second-line  treatment includes DMARDs and analgesics for pain control(1) NSAIDs symptoms  often improve within days, with full efficacy noted in 23 months(1) Ibuprofen Naproxen Both naproxen and celecoxib were shown to not increase blood pressure in a double blind RCT assessing safety in patients 217  years of age with JIA(35) Tolmetin sodium Diclofenac Indomethacin Steroids Intraarticular corticosteroid injections commonly used for oligoarticular arthritis; triamcinolone hexacetonide provides prolonged response(2) Systemic steroids are used for the management of severe systemic illness, while awaiting response to a DMARD, or for uveitis, but should generally be avoided as they carry risks of severe toxicities, growth retardation, and osteopenia(2) DMARDs  required in 3040%  of cases(1)  Non-biologic  DMARDs Methotrexate (MTX)(1,2) Half of children taking MTX experience MTX intolerance. Symptoms include GI and behavioral symptoms. Educationregarding early identification and prevention of MTX intolerance is important, as children can struggle to manage taking this medication(43) Sulfasalazine(1,2) Leflunomide(2) Biologic DMARDs(2) TNF-α  inhibitors(2) Etanercept Infliximab Adalimumab IL-1 blocking agents(2) Anakinra Rilonacept Canakinumab IL-6 blocking agent(1,2) Tocilizumab Researchers published a 2014 study demonstrating the efficacy and safety of tocilizumab over 104 weeks of treatment in patients with polyarticular JIA(20) Another 2014 study investigated the efficacy of tocilizumab on radiologic joint damage when prescribed to patients with polyarticular JIA for whom MTX was ineffective(21) Results showed the effectiveness of tocilizumab on halting the progression of radiologic joint damage, with most participants free of disease progression after 2 years of treatment Abatacept(2) Rituximab(2) In 2019, the American College of Rheumatology (ACR) published an update of its 2013 recommendations for the medical therapy of children with systemic JIA. One key change is that initial treatment with DMARDs is recommended over NSAID monotherapy for polyarthritis. Specific recommendations for DMARDS are not included, with the exception for TNFi for sacroiliitis; rituximab is considered only after TNFi, abatacept, and tocilizumab have been tried. Recommendations for the use ofbiologics versus nonbiologics  are included. Janus kinase inhibitors and interleukin17  and interleukin-12/23  inhibitors are listed as drugs with promising effects in current studies. Lastly, new recommendations include escalation of therapy for children with low disease activity to achieve complete disease control(42) A 2016 study compared the long-term  safety and efficacy of etanercept and adalimumab with that of MTX in patients with JIA(37) Data from a German register of patients with polyarticular, systemic, enthesitis-related,  and psoriatic JIA and data from its followup  register was analyzed to determine rates of adverse events associated with each treatment option Results indicated that patients treated with etanercept and adalimumab experienced significantly more serious adverse events and infections than those treated with MTX alone; treatment with etanercept and adalimumab did not lead to a significantly increased risk of developing a malignant disease compared with MTX; treatment with etanercept alone was linked with an increased incidence of irritable bowel disease and uveitis compared with treatment with etanercept in combination with MTX or MTX alone Overall, study data confirmed sufficient long-term  tolerability of etanercept and adalimumab for JIA; the increased adverse events experienced while taking these medications may be due to a more serious disease course than that in patients treated with MTX alone Another 2016 study analyzed blood serum levels of TNF-α  in 41 children with nonsystemic JIA to determine its relationship with longterm  efficacy of etanercept(38) Serum levels of TNF-α,  both free and bound to etanercept, were measured just before starting treatment with etanercept and at 6week follow-up  At follow-up,  levels of TNF-α  were increased despite etanercept being an anti-TNF-α  drug; the increased levels consisted almost entirely of TNFα  bound to etanercept; the children who demonstrated the most significant response to etanercept therapy were also those who had increased levels of TNFα  at follow-up;  84% of the children with the largest increase in TNFα  serum levels continued to receive the drug 5 years after initiating treatment Results indicated that increased levels of TNF-α/etanercept  complexes in blood serum after beginning treatment with etanercept can be used to predict the longterm  efficacy of the drug Treatment with DMARDs has been shown to reduce the risk of uveitis onset in JIA(39) Data from the National Paediatric Rheumatological Database in Germany that was entered over an 11-year  time span was analyzed to determine the impact of treatment with MTX and/or TNF inhibitors on the onset of uveitis in JIA patients(39) Results indicated that the risk for uveitis significantly decreased when patients were treated with MTX, TNF inhibitors, or a combination of MTX and a TNF inhibitor in the year before uveitis onset Treatment with MTX within the first year following diagnosis and combination therapy with MTX and a TNF inhibitor had the highest effect in reducing the risk of uveitis onset
diagnostic tests completed: Diagnostic tests completed: Usual tests for this condition:
Complete blood count (CBC)  elevated white blood cell count indicative of systemic arthritis; check for lymphopenia, reactive thrombocytosis, and anemia(1)
Joint fluid aspiration to rule out infection(1)
Synovial biopsy only if synovial fluid aspiration not possible or with suspected infection despite negative synovial fluid culture(1)
ECG for suspected pericarditis if orthopnea present(1)
Radionuclide scans if infection or malignancy suspected(1)
Slit-lamp  examinations for uveitis; should be continued on a yearly basis throughout adulthood, as signs and symptoms of uveitis develop later, when visual acuity is already compromised(4)
Elevated inflammatory markers (e.g., erythrocyte sedimentation rate [ESR], C-reactive protein [CRP]) indicative of disease activity(1)
Presence of autoimmune markers (e.g., RF, human leukocyte antigen B27, ANA+, anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide [anti CCP] antibodies)associated with poor prognosis(3)
Note: ANA tests are not useful for diagnosis, as many healthy children are commonly positive.The test cannot distinguish a healthy child from a child with JIA(4)
Note: RF tests are also not useful for diagnosis, as many children with JIA do not test positive for this(4)
Diagnostic imaging: MRI, ultrasonography (US), and CT scan assist with diagnosing and monitoring the condition(1)
MRI  assesses synovial hypertrophy, cartilage degeneration, and clinical responsiveness to treatment.(1) MRI with contrast is the gold standard for identifying TMJ arthritis in JIA(28)

A 2014 published systematic review reported that MRI is an accurate diagnostic tool for evaluating early and intermediate changes in the TMJ in patients with JIA. There is insufficient evidence to indicate whether MRI is an accurate diagnostic method for detecting JIA in the spinal and sacroiliac joints(23)

Contrast-enhanced  MRI of the knee with particular attention to synovial thickening at the infrapatellar and cruciate ligaments can be helpful to discriminate between children with JIA and unaffected children(36)

Radiographs  detect joint changes such as soft tissue swelling, periosteal reaction, juxta-articular  demineralization, loss of joint space, articular surface erosion, subchondral cyst formation, and sclerosis(1)
Gold standard for viewing structural joint damage in patients with chronic arthritis(24)
Sharp/van der Heijde score (SHS)  pediatric scoring system to detect radiographic joint damage (joint space narrowing) and erosion progression in the hands and wrist(26)
CT  used to assess skeletal anatomy and any abnormalities;(1,7) not first choice of diagnostic modality due to high radiation dose(7)
US  assesses cartilage, joint effusions, cortical erosions, synovial thickening, and cysts in the synovium(7)
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies (e.g., ice or heating pack) or alternative therapies (e.g., acupuncture) and whether they help. Document any use of supplements such as calcium, vitamin D, or folic acid(3)
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether patient has had occupational or physical therapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpfulDocument what makes symptoms better or worse and the length of time each item is

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: performed before symptoms come on or are easedUse body chart to document location and nature of symptomsDocument nature of symptoms (e.g., constant vs. intermittent, sharp, dull, aching, burning, numbness, tingling, stiffness).Depending on the age of the child, both parent(s)/caregiver and child should be questioned about symptomsUse a visual analog scale (V AS) or 010  scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment (specifically address if pain is present now and how much) -Pediatric pain evaluations(9) -Wong-Baker  FACES Pain Rating Scale -FLACC (Face, Legs, Activity, Cry and Consolability) Scale -Hester’s Poker Chip Tool -010  Numeric Pain Intensity Scale -Brief Pain InventoryDocument changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (A.M., mid-day,  P.M., night); also document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variablesDocument number of wakings/night. Poor sleep quality is associated with JIA(2)Document other symptoms patient may be experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/or symptoms that could be indicative of a need to refer to physician -Fever, fatigue, malaise, weight loss(1) -Macrophage activation syndrome (MAS)(2) -Systemic corticosteroid treatment increases the risk of osteopenia(2) -Uveitis,(2,19)cataracts,(1,2) glaucoma,(1,2,24)blindness(1,2) -Short stature, micrognathia (with TMJ involvement)(1)Document any use of supplemental oxygen -Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask the patient about other problems, including diabetes, cancer, heart disease, psychiatric disorders, orthopedic and disorders Children with JIA also experience psychosocial distress, depression, and social estrangement(10)
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including OTC drugs)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask the patient about other symptoms he or she may be experiencing

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: Document the patient’s participation in play/leisure activities -Authors of asystematic review found decreased physical activity and increased time spent in sedentary behaviorin children with JIA compared to healthy peers. This can then lower physical fitness and increase symptoms in these patients(44) -Children with JIA may have difficulties in school and/or have specific educational needs(1)
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: Document how much assistance the patient requires with ADLs. Note any adaptive equipment used
social and occupational history.living environment: Document any stairs, number of floors in home, with whom patient lives (caregivers, family members). Identify if there are barriers to independence in the home; any modifications necessary?

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting) -Anthropometric characteristics -Assess height, weight, and BMI. Compare to age and sex norms. Decreased height and weight for age is associated with JIA(27)
relevant tests and measures.arousal attention cognition: -Arousal, attention, cognition (including memory, problem solving) -Assess attention, cognition – Modified Mini-Mental  State Examination (MMSE) -Assistive and adaptive devices -Assess the patient’s need for and/or use of assistive and adaptive equipment for ADLs and functional mobility -Balance -Assess for static and dynamic balance with Pediatric Balance Scale (PBS), Bruininks-Oseretsky Test of Motor Proficiency, Second Edition (BOT-2) balance subscale, or Peabody Developmental Motor Scales, Second Edition (PDMS-2)  balance subscale -Cardiorespiratory function and endurance -Children with JIA may have decreased aerobic and anaerobic capacity(11) -Treadmill walking, graduated treadmill test, or isokinetic cycle ergometer are reliable measures for children with JIA(12) -Based on a Canadian study of 74 children, age range 8–16  years, with JIA -Exercise testing and completion of functional activity questionnaires in each testing session, for a total of 2 testing sessions; the second testing session occurred 2–6 weeks after the initial test -Treadmill testing, measuring maximal and submaximal oxygen uptake, had high reliability -Small improvements between test 1 and test 2 seen in walking efficiency and peak power -Ergonomics/body mechanics -Assess child’s body mechanics during functional tasks such as carrying and lifting -Functional mobility  (including transfers, etc.) -Assess child’s ability to transition in/out of positions such as sitting, standing, supine, kneeling -The WeeFIM can be used(13) -Gait/locomotion -Observe patient’s ability to ambulate without limping or complaints of pain -May be best assessed and addressed by physical therapist (PT) -Joint integrity and mobility -Assess TMJ and bilateral upper extremity joint mobility and note number of joints affected and/or any abnormalities/ deformity. TMJ hypomobility is frequently asymptomatic but extremely common(28) -Use the Paris Mobility Scale to document degree of intervertebral hypo/hypermobility present and note any complaints of pain or discomfort -Muscle strength -Assess trunk and bilateral upper/lower extremity strength with manual muscle testing (MMT) unless joints are acutely inflamed -For younger children or children who have difficulty understanding and following directions, assess muscle strength while the child performs functional activities -Document any abnormality, asymmetry, or complaints of pain -Neuromotor developmentBayley Scales of Infant Development–III  (BSID-III),(11) PDMS-2,  BOT-2,  or Tufts Assessment of Motor Performance(13) -Observation -Inspect skin for breakdown, rashes  -Palpation -Palpate for joint space narrowing, bone erosions, and other joint abnormalities.(24) Frequency and localization of joint damage and abnormalities vary greatly depending on the subtype of JIA -Rheumatoid nodules on the elbow and over Achilles tendon may be present in severe courses of polyarticular RF+ JIA(2) -Italian researchers evaluated the presence and progression of radiographic joint damage in the hand and wrist in 186 children with JIA. The wrist had greater progression of joint damage and overall joint erosion compared to the metacarpal phalangeal joints. The hamate and capitate were most frequently identified as having erosions. Patients with polyarticular JIA presented with a greater frequency of joint erosion and joint space narrowing compared to those with oligoarticular JIA(26) -Document any complaints of pain/discomfort upon joint palpation and soft tissue -Perception  (e.g., visual field, spatial relations) -Assess visual motor skills and visual field testing, as uveitis is a concern in children with JIA -Review results of testing performed by optometrists or ophthalmologists if possible -Posture -Observe the patient’s sitting and standing posture and note any abnormalities -Range of motion -Assess (e.g., goniometric measurements) bilateral upper extremity active and passive ROM and note any complaints of pain/discomfort or asymmetry. Screen for lower extremity limitations in motion. Referral to PT may be appropriate if limitations are found -If cervical spine is involved, there may be limited neck extension(2) -Patients with JIA may also have decreased ROM at the hip(2) -Assess TMJ active and passive ROM -Self-care/activities  of daily living  (objective testing)WeeFIM, Klein-Bell Activities of Daily Living Scale, or Vineland Adaptive Behavior Scales(13) -Sensory testing -Assess bilateral upper extremity dermatomes for light touch, pinprick (dull/sharp), temperature -Special tests specific to diagnosis –JIA assessments -Juvenile Arthritis Functional Status Index (JASI)(16) – self-report  of 100 statements on a 7-point  scale in dimensions of self-care, domestic, mobility, school, and extracurricular activities -Childhood Arthritis Health Profile (CAHP)(16) – parent-report  questionnaire on physical, emotional, social, and schoolwork limitations, pain, psychosocial behavioral issues, expectations for general health, general symptoms, and specific treatments -Juvenile Arthritis Functional Assessment Report (JAFAR)(13) – based on the Juvenile Arthritis Functional Assessment Scale (JAFAS); self-report  or parent report of self-care, mobility tasks -JAFAS(13) – standardized assessment of 10 tasks that use all joints, in domains of physical activities and ADLs -Juvenile Arthritis Quality of Life Questionnaire (JAQQ)(13) – questionnaire covering dimensions of gross motor, fine motor, psychosocial, systemic symptoms, and pain -Childhood Arthritis Impact Measurement Scale (CAIMS)(13) – adapted from the Arthritis Impact Measurement Scale (AIMS), using physical disability and pain dimensions -Pediatric QOL assessments -Pediatric Evaluation of Disability Inventory (PEDI)(11) -Revised Activity Scale for Kids (ASK)(12) -Habitual Activity Estimation Scale(12) -Children Activity Limitations Questionnaire(8) -Child Health Questionnaire (CHQ)(14) -Physical Summary Score (PhS)(14)  -Pediatric Rheumatology Quality of Life Scale (PRQL)(14) -Medical Outcomes Study 36-item  Short Form Health Survey (SF-36)(15) -General Health Questionnaire (GHQ-30)(15) -Childhood Health Assessment Questionnaire (C-HAQ  or CHAQ)(12) -Authors of a study compared agreement between the C-HAQ,  adolescent-specific  C-HAQ,  and the HAQ at the initial presentation to a pediatric rheumatologist and at a 1-year  follow-up  in adolescents with JIA. The scores are not interchangeable, but there is moderate to high agreement between the measures. If using these measures into adulthood, the differences should be taken into account(45)

cryotherapy contraindications: Avoid applying cold over areas of peripheral nerve regeneration, peripheral vascular disease, or compromised circulation
cryotherapy precautions: Use caution with patients who are hypertensive, as cold can cause a transient increase in blood pressure; discontinue treatment if there is an elevation in blood pressure
Use caution with patients who are hypersensitive to cold or who have thermoregulatory disorders
Avoid aggressive treatment with cold modalities over an acute wound
Use caution when applying cold over a superficial peripheral nerve or over areas of diminished sensation
Use caution with very young or very old patients and with patients with impaired cognition
Use of cryotherapy with patients who have an aversion to cold may be counterproductive if being used to promote muscle relaxation and decrease pain
Avoid applying over areas of diminished thermal sensation, infection, acute inflammation, or where liniments or heat rubs have been applied
Avoid applying over areas of vascular insufficiency or vascular disease, recent hemorrhage or potential hemorrhage, or areas of known malignancy
Avoid use in any situation practitioner determines to be unreliable (e.g., impaired cognition, language difficulties)
other: Caution should be used regarding the amount of resistance prescribed for exercise programs, as excessive resistive exercises can cause increased inflammation of the joints
Pain should be respected; pain management is an important factor in patient compliance with therapy programs

Children with systemic JIA are at risk for developing MAS, a life-threatening  condition characterized by fever, organomegaly, cytopenia, hyperferritinemia, hypertriglyceridemia, hypofibrinogenemia, and coagulopathy. Stop treatment and notify the referring physician immediately(2,29)
Children with JIA have a lower bone mineral density and more fractures than children without JIA(17)

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: Diagnosis/need for treatment Diagnosis is based upon symptoms and pattern (i.e., morning stiffness > 1hour, distribution of joint inflammation, laboratory and radiograph findings)(25) Children with JIA are optimally cared for using a multidisciplinary team approach. Pediatric and adolescent healthcare professionals should have extensive knowledge in the assessment and treatment of JIA Occupational therapy is warranted to facilitate the development of independence in completing functional, age-appropriate daily activities within the home and school communityminimize joint inflammation and prevent articular damage, pain management, maximize joint mobility and minimize joint deformity, maximize strength, facilitate fine motor skills and dexterity, improve bilateral coordination, and maximize age-appropriate  functional skills such as dressing and grooming  treatment -Twenty-eight  patients with JIA, mean age 15.5 years, compared to 110 healthy children who served as controls for the assessment of TMJ mobility -Significant reduction in orofacial pain frequency and intensity was reported, along with a significant increase in TMJ function -TMJ mobility was still significantly decreased compared to the control group after treatment intervention . assessment plan of care.rule out: Differential diagnosis includes Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) Dermatomyositis Mixed connective tissue disease Sarcoidosis Legg-Calve-Perthes  disease Toxic synovitis Growing pains Septic arthritis Osteomyelitis Viral infection Lyme disease Reactive arthritis (postinfectious arthritis, Reiter’s syndrome, rheumatic fever) Inflammatory bowel disease (ulcerative colitis, Crohn’s disease) Hemoglobinopathies Rickets Leukemia Bone tumors Neuroblastoma Vasculitis Henoch-Schönlein  purpura Kawasaki disease Farber disease Trauma – accidental or abuse Scleroderma(2) Autoimmune hepatitis(2)
prognosis: There is no known cure for JIA,(25) but 50–60%  of children enter remission by adulthood, with varying functional ability(1) –Remission is defined as no active arthritis, fever, rash, serositis, or generalized lymphadenopathy attributable to JIA, no active uveitis, normal ESR or CRP, no disease activity for 6 months(3) –Children with RF+ are at an increased risk of JIA persisting into adulthood

A poorer prognosis is associated with active disease at 6 months, polyarticular JIA, extended oligoarticular disease course, female sex, RF+ and ANA+ , persistent morning stiffness, rapid appearance of joint erosion, and hip joint involvement(1)
Children with oligoarthritis who are ANA + and have onset of arthritis before 6 years of age are at risk for developing chronic uveitis(2)

Children with polyarticular JIA often have more prolonged course of active joint inflammation(2) –Predictors of severe and prolonged disease include young age at onset, RF seropositivity or rheumatoid nodules, presence of anti-CCP  antibodies, and many affected joints(2) –Involvement of hip, hand, and wrist may indicate a poor prognosis and may lead to functional impairments(2)

Early treatment including biological therapy has improved the prognosis of children with JIA. Authors of a study (N = 60) in which 42% of the patients were being treated with biologics found both cardiovascular fitness and body composition in children with oligoarticular and polyarticular JIA are comparable to those of healthy control subjects. However, they do have decreased muscle strength and bone health compared to control subjects(46)

Authors of a study described disease activity and general health status for patients with JIA 30 years after disease onset(40) –A group of patients who were initially referred to a Norwegian hospital in the 1980s were re-examined  at 15 and a median of 23 years after onset –Disease activity was assessed by physician examination, number of active joints, patient report of well-being,  and the remission criteria for JIA. Self-report  measures were used to assess general health status  –At 30-year  follow up, 59% of the total cohort of patients were in remission off medication, 7% were in remission on medication, and 34% had active disease. Although disease activity improved from years 15 to 30, patient-reported health status and disability did not improve(40)

Children with JIA are less physically active and have lower fitness levels when compared to healthy peers(41) –Based on a study that used accelerometry data for 61 patients with JIA and a control group of 2055 healthy children(41) –JIA patients were assessed for disease activity, functional ability, physical capacity, and pain. Daily physical activity was measured with an accelerometer worn during waking hours for 1 week and a daily activity log. Physical activity data for the control group were taken from 2 prior studies –Fifty-seven  percent of JIA patients had below-average  values for maximal physical capacity during initial assessment, though most patients showed relatively mild disease activity and pain and were physically well-functioning –Accelerometer monitoring indicated lower levels of physical activity among the JIA patients when compared to the control group. JIA patients with hip or ankle involvement had the lowest levels of physical activity, causing them to have an even higher risk of an inactive lifestyle

Children with systemic JIA have an increased rate of mortality compared to other children with other forms of JIA, mostly due to infection associated with chronic glucocorticoid treatment, MAS, and amyloidosis.(22) The mortality rate for children hospitalized with systemic JIA and MAS is estimated to be 6%(29)
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Referral to other disciplines Psychologist Pediatric ophthalmologist Nutritionist Social worker Educational resource specialist Pediatric radiologist Pediatric orthopedist Physical therapist Pediatric rheumatologist Pediatric rheumatology clinical nurse specialist
other considerations: There may be orthopedic complications, including leg-length discrepancy and flexion contractures of the knees, hips, and wrists(2)
Diet considerations include adequate calcium, iron, protein, and caloric intake(1)
Children with JIA are twice as likely to have decreased bone mineral composition. Decreased bone mass may affect muscle strength(11)

Children with chronic illness such as JIA are at risk for high rates of school absence, placing them at risk for difficulty with academic performance and peer relations(31) –A United States 12-month  prospective study compared children treated with and without TNF-α  inhibitors. There was no difference in infection rates between groups; however, a higher number of involved joints and higher values on the C-HAQ  were associated with increased missed school days and number of physician sick visits regardless of TNF-α treatment

Authors of a study found that children with JIA are less likely to participate in club sports compared to healthy controls. Reported barriers to participation included both physical and psychosocial factors. Education on encouraging physical activity and the consequences of low physical activity is important in children with JIA(47)
treatment summary: Advances in medications to manage the disease process in children with JIA have changed the focus of treatment for this population. An active lifestyle is encouraged and can be accomplished without increasing disease flares. Decreasing pain and improving aerobic capacity, muscle strength, ADLs, and overall QOL through exercise is recommended(48)

Exercise –Authors of a literature review found moderate-level  evidence thatexercise training 30–50  minutes, 2–3 times per week over the course of 12–24  weeks can decrease pain and improve ROM, knee strength, functional capability, and QOL in patients with JIA(48)  –Authors of a systematic review evaluated the efficacy of exercise interventions in improving outcomes in children with JIA. Exercise interventions included aquatics, strengthening, proprioceptive activities, aerobic exercises, and Pilates exercises -Exercise therapy was well tolerated in patients with JIA -Exercise therapy may have a beneficial effect on CHAQ scores, pain, muscle strength, activity capacity, and QOL in patients with JIA -Due to wide variations in the studies, specific recommendations on the type, intensity, frequency, and duration of exercise could not be determined –Authors of a study (N = 13) evaluated the impact of pedometer use on the physical activity and functional walking capacity of children with JIA. Patients were not given the pedometer until after week 6.Patients’ 6MWT significantly increased from baseline to 6 weeks and from baseline to the end of the study, indicating that they increased their physical activity and functional walking capacity. However, the effect of the addition of pedometers onfunctional walking capacity measured by the 6MWT could not be determined(49) –Authors of a study (N = 62) compared the effects of task-oriented  activity training with real materials from daily life (group 1) to task-oriented  activity training via video-based  games (group 2)(50) -Exercises were performed 3 times per week for 8 weeks -Group 1: Task-oriented  activities included training with materials such as clothes, spoons, pencils, buttons, ropes, screw sets, and other coordination tools -Group 2: Task-oriented  activities were performed using video-based  games in which the patient mirrored movements on the screen and wasscored on angle, speed, and fluency -Both groups were effective treatments, but group 2 had statistically higher scores in upper limb strength, palmar pinch strength, activity performance, participation, and satisfaction compared to group 1

Splinting/orthotic fabrication –Splints used for contracture management(1) –Most used for TMJ. Functional orthodontic appliances can be made that help to alter the mandibular position. Few studies have been done, but some have shown benefits. There are safe devices to use(51) –TMJ stabilization splint is a safe and low-cost  treatment intervention to reduce orofacial pain and improve TMJ function as an alternative to oral medications(30) -Danish researchers evaluated changes in orofacial pain and TMJ function following 8 weeks of stabilization splint

desired outcomes: Decreased pain with functional activities–V AS

Safe and independent performance of functional activities, using joint protection techniques and adaptive equipment asneeded–WeeFIM(13)–Klein Bell Activities of Daily Living(13)–Vineland Adaptive Behavior Scales(13)–JASI(16)–CAHP(16)–JAFAR(13)–JAFAS(13)
Improved QOL–PEDI(11)–C-HAQ(12)–ASK(12)–Habitual Activity Estimation Scale(12)–Children Activity Limitations Questionnaire(8)–JAQQ(13)–CAIMS(13)–CHQ(14)–PhS(14)–PRQL(14)–SF-36(15)–GHQ-30(15)

maintenance or prevention: Ongoing patient and family education with particular attention to psychosocial and educational needs. Behavioral strategies may be required for dealing with chronic pain and potential noncompliance. Education regarding available resources (e.g., support groups) is important(1) Children require ongoing information about treatments and lifestyle management, strong social support, community advocacy, and active involvement in their own health decision-making  to increase their confidence, ability to manage pain, and resourcefulness for self-management(32) –In a 2012 published systematic review, Australian researchers studied the experiences of children living with JIA from 27 studies. Six major themes were identified: aversion to being different, striving for normality, stigma and misunderstanding, suspension in uncertainty, managing treatment, and desire for knowledge(32) –Researchers concluded that JIA disrupts a child’s sense of normality and impairs his or her capacity for social participation. Children with JIA have a sense of being misunderstood and stigmatized. They feel constantly caught between having hope and control over their bodies and overwhelming pain and despair(32)

In young adulthood approximately 20% of patients experience disability not directly related to arthritis (e.g., difficulties with lifetime adjustment and employment). Counseling may be necessary to support psychosocial adaptation(2)

Followup with multidisciplinary team on an ongoing, regular basis to optimally manage and treat the patient’s signs and symptoms  Regular preventive eye exams are necessary due to the increased risk of developing eye disease (e.g., uveitis); recommended every 3–4months for oligoarticular JIA and for those ANA+, especially for 3 years after diagnosis(1) Proper screening with MRI contrast to identify the presence of TMJ arthritis as early as possible. If TMJ arthritis is left untreated, it can lead to micrognathia, poor mouth opening, facial dysmorphism, and chronic pain and disability. TMJ arthritis is diagnosed in advanced stages in many children since they are typically asymptomatic in the early stages(28)

Ongoing therapeutic intervention at varying intervals of a child’s disease progression to effectively manage joint protection, provide work/education simplification techniques to prevent pain and deformity of joints, improve strength and flexibility, and maximize independence in daily activities
